message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of hypotension, bradycardia, and ECG changes consistent with hyperkalemia. Calcium chloride is the best option to stabilize the cardiac membrane and protect against ventricular fibrillation. Glucagon and insulin can also help, but they take longer to work. Polystyrene sulfonate can help with hyperkalemia, but it takes time to work and is not the best option for a patient with hemodynamic instability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperkalemia, which can cause peaked T waves and widened QRS complexes on ECG. Calcium chloride is the immediate therapy for hyperkalemia. Glucagon and polystyrene sulfonate can also help lower potassium levels but they are not as fast-acting as calcium chloride. Subcutaneous insulin is used to treat hyperglycemia and does not affect potassium levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG findings suggest hyperkalemia, which can be caused by chemotherapy-induced lysis of tumor cells. Calcium chloride should be given first to stabilize the myocardium, and then other measures like insulin and polystyrene sulfonate can be used to lower potassium levels. Glucagon is not useful in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has ECG changes consistent with hyperkalemia, and the treatment for hyperkalemia is calcium chloride. Glucagon and subcutaneous regular insulin can also be used to treat hyperkalemia, but calcium chloride is the best first-line option. Polystyrene sulfonate is used to treat hyperkalemia in nonemergent situations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with electrolyte abnormalities and ECG changes, which suggests hyperkalemia. Calcium chloride is used as a treatment for hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac myocytes. Glucagon and insulin are treatments for hypoglycemia. Polystyrene sulfonate is a treatment for hyperkalemia, but it works by binding to potassium in the gut, which takes hours to have an effect and is not appropriate in this acute setting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG findings suggest hypocalcemia, which can be caused by chemotherapy-induced tumor lysis syndrome. Calcium chloride is used to treat hypocalcemia. Glucagon is used to treat beta-blocker overdose, subcutaneous regular insulin is used for hyperkalemia, and polystyrene sulfonate is used to treat hyperkalemia as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperkalemia, which can cause the ECG changes and weakness. Calcium chloride will stabilize the myocardium and should be given first. Insulin and polystyrene sulfonate can be used to decrease potassium, but they take longer to have an effect. Glucagon can also be used in combination with insulin, but it is not the best initial choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting signs of hyperkalemia, with peaked T waves and widened QRS complexes on the ECG, and bibasilar crackles and scattered wheezing on chest auscultation. Calcium chloride can help stabilize myocardial cell membranes, improving cardiac contractility and preventing further arrhythmias. Glucagon and subcutaneous regular insulin are options for hyperkalemia management, but calcium chloride should be given first. Polystyrene sulfonate is used for treatment of hyperkalemia via exchange resins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest hyperkalemia, which can be confirmed by the ECG changes. Calcium chloride is the first step in the management of severe hyperkalemia as it can rapidly protect the heart from arrhythmias. Glucagon and insulin can be used to shift potassium into cells but are not effective in the acute setting. Polystyrene sulfonate can be used to remove potassium from the body but takes hours to become effective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing hyperkalemia due to the chemotherapy and ECG findings. Calcium chloride is the first-line treatment for hyperkalemia as it stabilizes cardiac membranes. Glucagon and subcutaneous regular insulin are options for treating hyperkalemia, but they take longer to work than calcium chloride. Polystyrene sulfonate helps remove potassium from the body but is not recommended in acute hyperkalemia.
